title: Protocol Village: Binance Enables Deposits, Withdrawals for Ethereum on zkSync Era
author: Bradley Keoun
description: The latest in blockchain tech upgrades, funding announcements and deals.
cleaned_text: Protocol Village: Binance Enables Deposits, Withdrawals for Ethereum on zkSync Era The latest in blockchain tech upgrades, funding announcements and deals. Sept. 7: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange by trading volume, has "completed the integration of Ethereum ( [ETH](https://www.coindesk.com/price/ethereum/)) on the network," according post Thursday](https://www.binance.com/en/support/announcement/binance-completes-integration-of-ethereum-eth-on-zksync-era-network-opens-deposits-and-withdrawals-ee1c87b20f2248618446bf21d72556ed). "Deposits and withdrawals for Ethereum (ETH) tokens are now open on the zkSync Era network." Protocol Village is a regular feature of [The Protocol](https://www.coindesk.com/newsletters/the-protocol/), our weekly newsletter exploring the tech behind crypto, one block at a time. [Sign up here](https://www.coindesk.com/newsletters/the-protocol/) to get it in your inbox every Wednesday. Project teams can submit updates [here](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1nMthDF2ULhqXQuHTZ6cqWZFGKJUbCWY8tnVFeaU6RVs/viewform). Sept. 7: Dfinity Foundation said it has [launched a $1 million grant fund](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-dfinity-foundation-announces-partnership-with-the-municipality-of-lugano-and-a-1-million-fund-for-lugano-blockchain-startups-301920835.html?tc=eml_cleartime) to support startups in Lugano, Switzerland, to build on the [Internet Computer](https://www.coindesk.com/price/internet-computer/) blockchain. Sept. 7: "JPMorgan is in the early stages of exploring a blockchain-based digital deposit token for speeding up cross-border payments and settlement, according to a person familiar with the work," Bloomberg [reported](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-09-07/jpmorgan-jpm-explores-blockchain-deposit-token-for-payment-settlement?cmpid=BBD090723_crypto&sref=3REHEaVI). "The deposit token would function differently from [JPM Coin](https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2020/10/27/jpmorgan-launches-jpm-coin-welcome-to-the-private-currency-era/), as it could be used to easily send money to clients of another bank, the person familiar with the work said. It is also well-suited for settlement of trades of tokenized securities, or financial instruments issued on a blockchain." Sept. 7: According to the dYdX Foundation, in report](https://dydx.foundation/blog/dydx-2023-semi-annual-ecosystem-report) Testnet #2. The current Public Testnet block time is approximately 1.8 seconds, and there have been over 2.9 million transactions and 2.9 million bonded tokens on the Testnet." DYdX, which is moving toward launch of its own blockchain built with Cosmos SDK, started [Testnet #2](https://dydx.exchange/blog/public-testnet-update) in running a Testnet #1 [since June](https://dydx.exchange/blog/public-testnet). Sept. 7: Trident Digital Group, a startup headed by Anthony DiMartino, Coinbase's head of risk strategies and institutitonal DeFi, raised $8M in a seed round, The Block [reported](https://www.theblock.co/post/249375/former-coinbase-execs-raise-8-million-for-fresh-take-on-crypto-lending). (White Star Capital, New Form, CMT Digital, Joint Effects, Permit Ventures) Sept. 7: OpenCover, a distributor of decentralized insurance aimed at cryptocurrency and Web3 platforms, has gone live on Base, Coinbase's layer-2 blockchain atop Ethereum. OpenCover, which raised $4 million in a seed round led by the likes of [NFX ](https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2020/09/22/facebooks-libra-co-founder-morgan-beller-departs-to-return-to-vc/)and Jump Crypto, [received a $200,000 funding bump from Coinbase to bolster its debut on Base](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2023/09/07/coinbase-backed-insurance-alternative-opencover-debuts-on-layer-2-blockchain-base/), according to OpenCover CEO Jeremiah Smith. Sept. 7: Compound, the DeFi lender, said Thursday in a newsletter it has launched on Base, the layer-2 blockchain from Coinbase. According to a [post currently a [bridged and [ETH market on Base](https://app.compound.finance/markets?market=weth-basemainnet). ETH and cbETH can be used as collateral to borrow bridged USDC, or cbETH to borrow ETH in each respective market." (The move was previously [publicized in a post](https://twitter.com/compoundfinance/status/1691134310844424192?s=20) on X (formerly Twitter) on Aug. 14.) Sept. 7: IoTeX, which supports an Ethereum-compatible (EVM) layer-1 [blockchain designed accommodate smart devices](https://onboard.iotex.io/introduction) the so-called " [Internet of Things](https://www.coindesk.com/tag/internet-of-things/)" (IoT), [publicized](https://twitter.com/iotex_dev/status/1699511884993495054) that it was one of 18 recipients of grants in the Ethereum Foundation's " [ERC-4337 Account Abstraction grant round](https://mirror.xyz/erc4337official.eth/hRn_41cef8oKn44ZncN9pXvY3VID6LZOtpLlktXYtmA)." According to [zero-knowledge potential of on-chain gaming, DeFi, DeSocial, and DePIN, among other applications.... The wallet uses zkSNARK to confirm account access: If users have the correct password, they can use a prover to generate valid proof that unlocks the account. The on-chain smart contract then verifies this proof to authenticate the transaction." Sept. 6: Story Protocol, set up to track intellectual property, conducted a follow-on fundraising in the third quarter, which, in conjunction to an earlier seed round, brings the total raised by the project to $54 million, according to the team. Investors include Andreessen Horowitz (a16z), Hashed and TPG Capital's David Bonderman. Sept. 6: Casa, a smart contract wallet provider, has [introduced a new feature](https://blog.keys.casa/eth-pay-wallet-relay/) "ETH Pay Wallet Relay" that "offers greater privacy for people who prefer their on-chain ETH addresses not to be connected to Casa," according to the team: "This relay uses the key from your ETH Pay Wallet to broadcast transactions to the ETH network." Sept. 5: Premium domain names might be worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, if not more, and have a carry cost of not more than $10 a year. But how would you get liquidity from a one-word domain name - worth a fortune on paper - if there are no buyers? Tokenization. D3 has closed a $5 million round, looking to do just that, as well as working with stakeholders such as ICANN to register Web3 top-level domains, the recognizable suffixes that direct domain names to servers. The round was led by Shima Capital with participation from Lightshift, Dispersion Capital, VentureSouq, Infinite Capital, C² Ventures, Arthur Hayes' Maelstrom and Identity Digital founder Paul Stahura. Sept. 5: [Endaoment.Org](http://endaoment.org/), which says it's the first on-chain 501(c)(3) nonprofit community foundation and donor-advised fund platform, has [expanded its platform to Base](https://endaoment.mirror.xyz/UvHuwzQEqQCdpltTAV-Bi2E28K6QfIO7Dm7Ikq89K3M). According to the team: "Originally available exclusively on Ethereum, Endaoment's deployment on Base makes crypto giving more accessible while reducing transaction costs, making small gifts more affordable for donors. The deployment brings more than 7,000 new verified donation endpoints for nonprofits across 150+ countries. This integration opens new donation revenue streams for nonprofits and ensures more funds go directly to a cause, rather than fees." Sept. 5: Blockchain network developer Cronos Labs has [started looking for eight startups](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2023/09/05/blockchain-developer-cronos-labs-kicks-off-search-for-participants-in-100m-accelerator-program/) to take part in the third cohort of its $100 million accelerator program aimed at supporting early stage crypto projects. The recruitment phase of the 12-week program [commenced](https://twitter.com/cronos_chain/status/1698906357288796575) Sept. 4 to coincide with the start of Korea Blockchain Week, which runs until Sept. 10, and has a particular focus on artificial intelligence. Sept. 5: Btrust, a non-profit organization that aims to "decentralize development of Bitcoin software," said it acquired Qala, an organization that trains African Bitcoin and Lightning engineers, on Sept. 1. Qala will be rebranded as the Btrust Builders Programme. Btrust was originally funded by [Block](https://investors.block.xyz/governance/leadership/default.aspx) and Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey along with the record producer Jay-Z. Sept. 4: Community members of dYdX, a decentralized derivatives-trading platform, [approved a governance proposal](https://dydx.foundation/blog/exploring-the-future-of-dydx) to make its [DYDX](https://www.coindesk.com/price/dydx/) token - currently on Ethereum's [ERC-20 token standard](https://dydx.foundation/blog/exploring-the-future-of-dydx) - [dYdX application-specific blockchain chain](https://dydx.exchange/blog/dydx-chain) built with Cosmos SDK. As part of the proposal, the community [agreed](https://snapshot.org/#/dydxgov.eth/proposal/0x17026e18317dc29fe745d3130246a83b1485612da9c97e7261e8f659cf33663c) to adopt an Ethereum smart contract commissioned by the dYdX Foundation that, once deployed, "would enable a permissionless and autonomous one-way bridge for the DYDX token to be migrated from Ethereum to the dYdX Chain." Sept. 4: [P2P.org](http://p2p.org/), an infrastructure provider on Ethereum that specializes in non-custodial staking, [announced on Aug. 31](https://p2p.org/economy/beyond-boundaries-large-scale-eth-staking-for-institutions/) that it "has launched a smart contract that enables users to stake up to 12,800 ETH from a single wallet in just one transaction instead of the usual 3,200 ETH limit," according to an email from the team. Sept. 4: Chronicle, a [blockchain data-oracle provider](https://chroniclelabs.org/), said it has [opened access to developers beyond the DeFi project MakerDAO's ecosystem](https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/09/05/multibillion-dollar-oracle-tool-chronicle-to-expand-outside-of-makerdao-ecosystem/). According to a press release, the Chronicle Protocol will launch first on Polygon zkEVM, an Ethereum layer-2 network and will "lay the foundation for integrating another of Chronicle's key partners, [Spark Protocol](https://www.sparkprotocol.io/)." Sept. 4: Trust Machines, a startup developing applications for the Bitcoin blockchain and led by Stacks co-creator Muneeb Ali, [announced](https://twitter.com/LeatherBTC/status/1697280119000453495?s=20) on Aug. 31 that it has acquired wallet assets from Hiro Systems (where Ali serves as chairman) and has now launched its own flagship Bitcoin wallet brand, [Leather](https://leather.io/). According to a [blog post](https://leather.io/blog/introducing-leather-the-bitcoin-wallet-for-the-rest-of-us), the wallet can L2 ( [STX](https://www.coindesk.com/price/stacks/)) and BRC-20 tokens, can be used to create, trade and transfer Ordinals, Stacks NFTs and Bitcoin Stamps. The former Hiro Wallet had 375,000 total installations and more than 100,000 monthly active users, according to the company. Sept. 4: Akash Network, a layer-1 blockchain built using Cosmos SDK to host a decentralized marketplace for cloud computing resources, [released its "Mainnet 6" upgrade](https://twitter.com/akashnet_) for its "Supercloud," [adding support for graphics processing units or GPUs](https://akash.network/blog/the-supercloud-for-ai-is-live/) - crucial for AI applications. Sept. 3: Stroom Network, a Kiev, Ukraine-based liquid-staking protocol on Bitcoin's Lightning Network that yield-farm on Ventures, 3: Argent, Ethereum [formed a partnership with Starknet Foundation](https://twitter.com/argentHQ/status/1697294615529865327) "to launch a new startup studio, dedicated to building the next generation of use cases in crypto. Hito Studios will seek to attract the best and brightest founders in crypto, helping them launch and spin out new startups on Starknet, while also providing initial investment. Hito Studios will also provide ongoing support in key areas, including ideation and team formation, engineering, legal and growth," according to a statement from the team. Aug. 31: Herodotus, a year-old, London-based startup developing infrastructure and tooling to help developers use [storage proof](https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/06/21/storage-proofs-touted-as-alternative-to-hack-prone-bridges-in-multichain-world/) technology on Ethereum, has [released an "on-chain of Starkware's shared prover. "Herodotus's new accumulator technology will enable users to read data from any point in Ethereum's history including the Genesis block," according to a press release shared with CoinDesk. The technological development could be useful "for account recovery mechanisms where verifying on-chain data from the past and present could play a vital role in triggering a dead man's switch, or for insurance protocols that rely on historical on-chain events for payouts or providing coverage," the team wrote. Aug. 31: ChainLight, a blockchain security firm specializing in smart-contract audits and on-chain monitoring, has [launched the second version of Relic Protocol](https://twitter.com/relicprotocol/status/1697256353327432131), a data indexing protocol, on zkSync, a layer-2 network atop Ethereum. According to a press release, the update provides developers with "trustless access to historical Ethereum data. Various protocols can use this wealth of previously inaccessible data to enhance functionalities. For instance, a lending protocol could use historical data to determine collateral volatility to adjust risk parameters trustlessly." Aug. 31: Interbank messaging system Swift and Web3 services platform Chainlink have [successfully transferred tokenized value across multiple private and public blockchains](https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/08/31/swift-chainlink-tokenization-experiment-successfully-transfers-value-across-multiple-blockchains/) in recent experiments, according to a [press release](https://www.swift.com/news-events/press-releases/swift-unlocks-potential-tokenisation-successful-blockchain-experiments) on Thursday. Aug. 31: Offchain Labs, the primary developer of the Ethereum optimistic rollup Arbitrum, on Thursday [released Arbitrum Stylus](https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/08/31/arbitrum-developer-courts-coders-who-already-know-webassembly-compatible-languages/), a new technical implementation that allows developers to build smart contracts using programming languages that are compatible with the WebAssembly industry standard format, also known as WASM. The [offering](https://twitter.com/OffchainLabs/status/1697232795268177987), now available for use on a test network, means developers can program with popular coding languages like Rust, C and C++ alongside languages that are compatible with the Ethereum Virtual Machine, or EVM standard, which is far more common among today's crypto developers. Aug. 30: "Bison Relay v0.1.8" update [introduces support for e-commerce sites](https://github.com/decred/decred-binaries/releases), with features including the "Simplestore" e-commerce infrastructure, "designed to facilitate the sale of digital-only goods such as images, videos, audio and files." Aug. 29: Casper Association, the Swiss-based organization that oversees the Casper blockchain, said its new ["1.5" upgrade](https://casper.network/en-us/news/casper-upgrade?hss_channel=tw-1061731562637553664) comes with unique "Speculative Execution Endpoint" feature, making the project "the only Layer-1 blockchain to enable the debugging of live, composable smart contracts on mainnet." Aug. 29: Oasis, a privacy-focused blockchain project, said its Sapphire main network has [integrated with Celer Network's cBridge](https://oasisprotocol.org/blog/sapphire-cbridge-integration-announcement), supporting the bridging BNB and MATIC. Aug. 29: Alchemy, a Web3 applications, has [added Base](https://alchemy.com/blog/base-on-alchemy), Coinbase's layer-2 Ethereum. Aug. 29: OpenZeppelin, a provider of blockchain security solutions, released the 2.0 version of its Defender platform, which provides automatic code analysis and can be used for ongoing monitoring of threats and automation of community governance proposals; developers and operators can use the tool to prevent and fix security issues pre- and post-deployment, according to the team. Aug. 29: The team behind Interlay, a decentralized network designed to provide [DeFi tooling for Bitcoin](https://gateway.pinata.cloud/ipfs/QmWp62gdLssFpAoG2JqK8sy3m3rTRUa8LyzoSY8ZFisYNB), announced plans for BOB, a new Bitcoin layer-2 network compatible with Ethereum's EVM software environment, "featuring Rust smart contracts compatible with Bitcoin libraries such as Lightning and Ordinals." Aug. 29: Polygon, the Ethereum scaling firm, is [releasing a toolkit for developers](https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/08/29/polygon-plans-chain-development-kit-for-zk-powered-networks-on-ethereum/) to help them build blockchains fueled [ by zero-knowledge (ZK) proofs](https://www.coindesk.com/learn/what-are-rollups-zk-rollups-and-optimistic-rollups-explained/). The Chain Development Kit (CDK) is an open-source codebase that developers can use to create their own customizable [ layer 2 chains](https://www.coindesk.com/learn/what-are-layer-2s-and-why-are-they-important/) using Polygon's ZK technology. Aug. 29: Helix, a decentralized orderbook exchange built on the Injective network, announced the launch of Helix Institutional, which "enables the trading of DeFi derivatives products in a permissioned, KYC-enabled environment." Currently Helix offers trading in with Cosmos software and featuring " [instant transaction finality](https://docs.injective.network/learn/introduction)" for financial applications. Aug. 28: Token withdrawals out of the Shibarium bridge are [now live and available to users](https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/08/28/shiba-inus-highly-anticipated-shibarium-bridge-is-now-fully-functional/), weeks after a [much-hyped launch quickly fizzled out](https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/08/22/shiba-inu-plans-shibariums-public-restart-days-after-botched-launch/) after being riddled with software bugs that led to millions of dollars in limbo on the network. Shibarium is an Ethereum layer-2 network, created via a fork of Polygon, that uses [SHIB](https://www.coindesk.com/price/shiba-inu/) tokens as fees in what is part of a broader plan to position Shiba Inu as a serious blockchain project. Aug. 27: Binance Labs wrote in a [blog post](https://www.binance.com/en/blog/ecosystem/binance-labs-invests-in-delphinus-lab-the-first-opensource-zkwasm-virtual-machine-to-support-next-era-of-web3-applications-3444797851566042967) that it has invested in Delphinus Lab, an infrastructure provider that is "leading the zkWASM space, where zero-knowledge (ZK) cryptography is deployed in [WebAssembly](https://blog.devgenius.io/webassembly-wasm-in-blockchain-f651a8ac767b) (WASM) environments." The funds will be used for development of Dephinus's zkWASM-based application rollup platform, zkWASM Hub, according to the post. WASM is a programming environment used by several blockchains, including [Cosmos](https://cosmwasm.com/) and [Polkadot](https://wiki.polkadot.network/docs/learn-wasm), often positioned as an alternative to the [Ethereum Virtual Machine](https://blog.thirdweb.com/evm-compatible-blockchains-and-ethereum-virtual-machine/) or EVM, that's [used by the Ethereum blockchain](https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2021/05/25/polkadots-gavin-wood-webassembly-is-the-future-of-smart-contracts-but-legacy-evm-is-right-now/) (and associated layer-2 networks) as as [Binance Chain](https://www.binance.com/en/blog/ecosystem/introducing-bnb-chain-the-evolution-of-binance-smart-chain-421499824684903436) and [Avalanche](https://support.avax.network/en/articles/5417030-what-is-the-ethereum-virtual-machine-evm). Aug. 24: Num out a Colombian peso-pegged token](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2023/08/24/colombian-peso-stablecoin-goes-live-on-polygon-aiming-for-10b-remittances-market/), named nCOP, on the Polygon network. Aug. 24: 1inch Network, an [aggregator](https://1inch.io/) of decentralized exchanges or it has Coinbase's new layer-2 blockchain, Aug. 24: Radix Publishing, publisher of code for Radix, a layer 1 smart-contract platform, said the final update of its two-year-old Olympia Protocol would be [released at the end of August](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2023/08/24/2730831/0/en/Radix-Announces-Irreversible-Update-Prior-To-Babylon-Mainnet-Migration.html), as part of the move toward Radix's Babylon mainnet migration at the end of September. Aug. 24: Pancake Swap, a decentralized exchange, has [expanded](https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/08/24/pancakeswap-version-3-goes-live-on-ethereum-layer-2-linea-mainnet/) to the blockchain Linea, from the on zkEVM, zkSync Era and Arbitrum. Aug. 23: Unstoppable Domains, a provider of digital identities that include crypto addresses, [said it has launched](https://unstoppabledomains.com/blog/categories/announcements/article/messaging-launch) a new "messenger feature powered by XTMP that allows owners of UD domains — or any Web3 wallet address — to chat with each other across the blockchain. You can use it for any kind of decentralized, end-to-end encrypted messaging. This could be as simple as making plans with a friend. You could even use it to negotiate an NFT trade or domain purchase. Many people in Web3 use their domain as an alias, meaning Messaging can support Web3 community building." Aug. 22: Farcaster, a protocol for decentralized apps including the Twitter-like Warpcast (where Ethereum's Vitalik use](/terms/), [cookies](/privacy/#cookies), and [do not sell my personal information](/privacy/#dnsmpi) has been updated. As part of their compensation, certain CoinDesk employees, including editorial employees, may receive exposure to DCG equity in the form of [stock appreciation rights](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/sar.asp), which vest over a multi-year period. CoinDesk journalists are not allowed to purchase stock outright in DCG.
